papers.abstract: In this paper, I develop an online website that assists users in answering the question, 'What do you need to remove in order to erase [thing] from [your life or society]?' through network visualization methods. This project subverts the typical data visualization strategy of working with extant data by encouraging users to produce data, demonstrating how data visualization techniques can constitute a way of thinking and creating rather than just analyzing and representing. However, this tool and its affordances are primarily a case study for a sociological approach to critical design in the Digital Humanities: By critically examining the tool itself (as well as the process that created it), I am able to pose the broader questions of (1) how does the creation of digital tools and projects reflect a theoretical interpretation of the social world and its processes, and (2) how can these interpretations constitute the data of sociological studies? In resolving these questions, I suggest that critical design can be viewed as theory, experiment, and data: designs constitute a social theory, data can be experimentally produced within this social theory, and encouraging reflective design can turn the social theories of design themselves into data.

events.Text: In this paper, I develop an online website that assists users in answering the question, 'What do you need to remove in order to erase [thing] from [your life or society]?' through network visualization methods.

Purpose: Assist users in answering questions about removals from life or society through network visualization
Implications: Potential for expanding study areas including social networks and personal item management systems

events.Text: This project subverts the typical data visualization strategy of working with extant data by encouraging users to produce data, demonstrating how data visualization techniques can constitute a way of thinking and creating rather than just analyzing and representing.

Context: Current data visualization strategies rely on analyzing preexisting datasets.
There exists a gap in promoting ways of thinking and creating rather than merely analyzing and representing data.
Purpose: To invert traditional roles in data visualization by prioritizing creation over analysis.
To redefine how data is handled and perceived through innovative means.
Method: Data visualization techniques were utilized to facilitate the creation of user-generated data.
Computational tools enhanced the interactivity between users and data generation processes.
Results: Users demonstrated increased engagement with data creation processes.
Visualizations became more dynamic and reflective of user interactions.
Analysis: This shift fosters a deeper understanding of data manipulation and its impact on perception.
It encourages iterative exploration, where creation drives further analysis and refinement.
Challenge: Potential challenges include managing real-time data feedback loops and ensuring consistent quality across iterations.
Ensuring fairness and accessibility in data ownership remains crucial.
Ethical: Issues concerning data ownership and privacy arise when users generate personal data.
Equitable distribution of benefits among diverse user groups needs careful consideration.
Implications: This approach has the potential to revolutionize education by making data creation accessible to learners.
It offers opportunities for developing new metrics and methodologies in data science education.

events.Text: However, this tool and its affordances are primarily a case study for a sociological approach to critical design in the Digital Humanities: By critically examining the tool itself (as well as the process that created it), I am able to pose the broader questions of (1) how does the creation of digital tools and projects reflect a theoretical interpretation of the social world and its processes, and (2) how can these interpretations constitute the data of sociological studies?

Secondary Object: tool itself (as well as the process that created it)

events.Text: In resolving these questions, I suggest that critical design can be viewed as theory, experiment, and data: designs constitute a social theory, data can be experimentally produced within this social theory, and encouraging reflective design can turn the social theories of design themselves into data.

papers.abstract: While popular histories of the ebook start in the 1990s, inventors were working on the form since at least the 1940s. In this article, I offer a media archaeological analysis of digital publishing patents to develop the ebook imagination, or the desires of readers and inventors for the future of reading on screen. Through an analysis of a corpus of 98 patents relating to ebooks, I demonstrate how the ebook imagination focused on the aesthetics of the book over focusing on replicating paper via a screen, which would later lead to the success of Amazon's Kindle in 2007.

events.Text: While popular histories of the ebook start in the 1990s, inventors were working on the form since at least the 1940s.
In this article, I offer a media archaeological analysis of digital publishing patents to develop the ebook imagination, or the desires of readers and inventors for the future of reading on screen.

Secondary Object: the desires of readers and inventors

Purpose: explore the desires of readers and inventors for the future of reading on screen
Results: offered a framework for analyzing digital publishing patents
Analysis: discusses the intersection of media history and ebook development
Challenge: limits due to rapidly changing technologies affecting modern eReading
Ethical: involves assumptions about historical influences on contemporary contexts
Implications: paves the way for further research on intersecting tech and user imaginings

events.Text: Through an analysis of a corpus of 98 patents relating to ebooks, I demonstrate how the ebook imagination focused on the aesthetics of the book over focusing on replicating paper via a screen, which would later lead to the success of Amazon's Kindle in 2007.

Primary Object: Through an analysis of a corpus of 98 patents relating to ebooks, I demonstrate how the ebook imagination focused on the aesthetics of the book over focusing on replicating paper via a screen, which would later lead to the success of Amazon's Kindle in 2007.
